Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 08:20PM Texgirl wrote: Was reading thru this thread and saw my name...shows you what chemo/menopausal mush I have for brain cells..I forgot that I sent in the hint ! On rereading the hint I will add a few clarifying points. 1. using a very long piece of dental floss or tape..take one end and run it up under your ring..TOWARD your hand (palm). 2.begin winding the longer length from the base of your ring OUTWARD toward your knuckle..It doesn't have to be extremely tight just close together . 3. When you have gotten to the knuckle or largest part of your finger..have someone hold that end to keep from coming loose. 4. Now, take the short end that is tucked under your ring..and slowly begin unwinding ..pulling gently toward your knuckle as u do so.. going round and round your ring..it should be moving your ring down and off your finger . Hope that helps...I did it again to make sure I didn't leave anything out...it only takes a few seconds........ Letha
Posts.Title: Tight wedding ring solution Binney4 Kate33

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2016 12:44PM Texgirl wrote: I rarely post on the site and realize that I should do it more often as we "long-timers" need to support those "in the trenches" so to speak. I was 11 years out in Early Feb. 2016 ( 7cm tumor/22/22+ nodes ). NEVER could I have foreseen this....when you are first diagnosed you can barely see past tomorrow..and you harbor the darkest of thoughts .Just want you all to know that yes,it is possible to have a good outcome and continue the life you always thought you would have. I am still taking Aromasin with minimal issues. Continue to see my Oncol. every 6 months . I appreciate EVERY birthday ! Drink a little too much wine and love every minute with my family. Here's to all you ladies who are just beginning this journey ....keep positive and surround yourself with positive friends and family. I'm always available for encouragement or a positive word.....love to you all.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 09:53AM Texgirl wrote: Cooked apples I use aprox. 8 large golden delicious apples ( feeds about 6) sliced, peeled or unpeeled Place in deep pot  and  add water to 1/2 depth of apples and cook till soft but not mushy Add 1 large box of vanilla cook and serve pudding.. stir. Serve hot. You may add a little sugar/splenda or even cinnamon prior to the pudding . This is so good.. great with almost any entree. I do serve it more in the Fall and Winter..  the guys love it.
Posts.Title: collecting recipes heatherpalmerton AlaskaDeb

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2014 08:44PM Texgirl wrote: I will be a 10 year survivor in Feb. of 2015. As I write that ,I am almost in disbelief ! Never in a million years would I have imagined myself this far "on the OTHER side " !  Yes, ladies, it is possible and I vote for keeping this topic as more and more of us will be breaking the barrier of long term survival ! I had a tumor approximately 7.5 cm and 22/22 positive nodes. So,if I can offer anything it is this : always remember "your best chance to get it right is the first time" . Find a specialist ( surgeon/oncologist)who deals with BC on a daily basis. Listen , discuss and plan with them your treatment.....and hit that cancer with everything in their arsenal....that they feel will benefit your situation. Pray . ( that should be in the #1 spot ) . Come to this community of women who can support you.. each and every day and night through your journey.   Remember,you are stronger than you will ever know. ....I pray that each of you will stand where I am today and feel that no, your life is not over but just beginning.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2006 11:36PM Texgirl wrote: I just returned from a lake vacation in late June . I waterskiied for the first time in 2 yrs. Did great ! Got up on the 1st try and didn't fall. I actually felt like a normal woman for a change ! I will say that I have been working out at the gym w/ a trainer and have advanced from a 1 lb free wt. to a 15 lb free wt. in the year and a half since dx. I believe that this has allowed me to go lymphadema free for so long...and I had a dissection and 22 nodes removed . So good luck to you..I am not going to do anything stupid but I am going to let the BC rule my life either....

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 05:07PM Texgirl wrote: Have been meaning to join you ladies and keep procrastinating..I have been an RN since '74.  Returned to school later and now have my BSN. I am currently not working but volunteering with the A.C.S. and Reach to Recovery. Have worked in hospitals,Dr's. offices and my very favorite School Health as a School Nurse. It was the best ! Had my 4yr cancerversary yesterday...and kept it to myself. I am grateful ,but, cannot understand how Annie Camel left us and  I am still doing well and NED. It just makes no sense...does it ? Due to my nursing background I had an initial difficulty with guilt... missing the dx myself. Although I now know that dense breasts make things worse..I still felt I should have known . Is that a commonality with other nurses?

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 03:47PM Texgirl wrote: I had my Diep in July '06...and have had smooth sailing with the "new girl".. no extra tweeks except for stage 2 and the nipple tattooing.I am just now getting more sensation in this recon. breast and my left shoulder and underarm..a strange sensation I have to say. I am also considering a P.M.  and when I go back for my next checkup in Feb.(3 yr) I am requesting it . With 21/21+ nodes I don't think it would be unreasonable to request it. As far as problems because we are stage III... I think it is more likely that some of us were reconstructed by a general plastic surgeon rather than a Reconstruction specialist....they may SAY they can do a DIEP but there are not that many in the US that have the broad range of expertise to actually carry out that procedure.Before I actually selected my surgeon , two said they could do it but that it had a high failure rate..blah, blah and that I'd like the GAP better.Needless to say I didn't go with them. I am thrilled w/ my result and feel I made a wise choice. It pays to shop around.
Posts.Title: stage 3 girls...how many tweeks to reonc. have you had if any at all? Naomi Naomi

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 01:07AM Texgirl wrote: Guess I want to hop in here and say a few words...yet trying to honor your requests...My tumor was 7.5 cm and I had 22/22+ nodes involved. I had an axillary dissection to level 2..pretty extensive...yet I still do not have lymphadema. I would hate that you are hesitating to have the surgery because you are  assuming that you will definitely develop lymphadema. Not all cases of lymphadema are due to the node dissections..some may occur to the surgery itself....you just cannot know ahead of time. I am IIIc and almost 4.5 yrs out...so don't automatically think that with a dx. of positive nodes you are doomed. Please listen to your Doc and try and understand her reasoning for wanting to do the procedure..she just wants for you an uneventful recovery and a long life ahead ! I wish you the very best in your decision.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 05:16PM Texgirl wrote: My port was placed in my inner arm prior to chemo...I went thru 6 of A/C and 6 Taxol without a problem. My thinking was that since I had had a level 2 AND ..I could not be using the L arm /hand at all for current or future chemo..IF I ruined the R hand/arm where would I be ? It isn't the fact that you have good vs bad veins,it is the possibility of damaging your veins by infiltration with chemo..it is not a pretty picture.  Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 12:12AM Texgirl wrote:  When I was initially treated in '05 and had just had my port placed with a new drug..to me anyway called Versed, I was excited that a drug like that could work so well.leaving u with no memory of the event...I decided that if only someone could come up with something like that that you could take at the beginning of treatment and then BAM ! treatment all done and we had only the foggiest of recollection of what we'd been thru for the last several months.......well ,perhaps it isn't the best of ideas but we all would prefer that our fears could be erased and the whole thing could turn out to be an awful nightmare. I must say though that most of my fears were just that....fears NOT reality.My what-ifs never happened and even the worst possibility never materialized.We sometimes can be our our own worst enemy. Always have a plan in the works.. in 2 months I will.........when I finish my first chemo..then make another plan.I will go sit at the beach when I get my rads completed... Keep that up and soon you will be done . I wish the best to all who are getting ready to take this first big step..remember you have alot of us here ready to support you along the way..you aren't alone.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 12:21PM Texgirl wrote:  I have had the "lightening bolts" ..out the corner of one eye in the recent past and the Opthamologist said as you age the  backwall of the inner eye sloughs off or peels off causing the flashes. Mine occur only rarely and there is no pain associated with it. He also mentioned something about the retina at the same time..and thanks to my chemo brain I cannot remember. I do remember that if the flashing is assoc. with pain or if the vision goes black u could have a detached retina which would mean emergency situation. Perhaps this helps you...........
Posts.Title: Brain mets question magsandmattsmom Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 12:37PM Texgirl wrote: How sad that she would risk a progression that could risk her life just because she doesn't want to know. I thought or would have hoped that those days were gone when women had that attitude. Much can be done today regarding cancer treatment ..you can ask the many women here who are stage IV and many yrs away from their dx. Chemo is NOT the chemo of even 10 yrs ago and is very doable even for older women.  I hope that you may convince her to continue with treatment and that you will share a long life  with her.It is NOT the end of the road for her .With regards to whether it is cancerous or not..only a biopsy will tell..not by feel nor MRI nor mammo. It has to be tested.I doubt that you would be able to get the ball rolling ,for as long as she is of sound mind would anyone go against the patient's wishes. YOu could of course enc. her to go and let the Dr. explain more in depth the situation...perhaps that would help. I wish you the best.
